segments.text: You're listening to the Conservative Conscience.
In Washington, politicians are full of half-trudes in hot air.
The Conservative Conscience is here to help you cut through the rhetoric and noise and
explore the politically right way to think about the issues.
You'll dive into one of the most insightful Conservative minds in America.
Conservative Review Senior Editor Daniel Horowitz.
Using pure common sense and ignoring the group think, Daniel breaks down the major issues
in Washington.
You are now entering the Conservative Conscience.
And welcome back to the Conservative Conscience.
This is your host, Daniel Horowitz here on November 20th.
A bright new holiday week and yes, as I sound, I am losing my voice here today, which is
why we're going to bring in a special guest in one moment.
First of all, I really want to wish you all a happy national transgender Remembrance Day.
This is what our buddies at the State Department and Tillerson are focused on.
But we're going to discuss today what they are not focused on.
Sadly, this week began with very tragic news.
Southwest Texas, 30 miles approximately from our border.
O'Hillyo Martinez, a brave border agent, was brutally killed in what is presumably an ambush
by illegal aliens.
His partner was seriously injured and is in a hospital.
And this is really or should really be the biggest news of the day.
But of course, you're not going to hear about it in the mainstream media.
Even a lot of the mainstream Conservative media, because we're all focused on the sideshow
of politics, we're not focused on the core function, the core job of the federal government's
sovereignty security.
We have a war at our southern border.
For a long time, I've been meaning to bring on the editor of Breitbart, Texas.
Brandon Darby has just done phenomenal work on the border drug cartels and what's going
on there.
And I figured what better day to bring him on, especially as I'm losing my voice.
And I need someone to help help take over and co-host today.
So it's no further ado to discuss more of what went down here specifically and what
we can and should be doing at the border.
It is my pleasure to bring aboard the Conservative conscience.
Brandon Darby.
Hey, Brandon, how are you?
Hey, Daniel, thanks for having me on.
Really great to have you with us today.
Like I said, I'm losing my voice, so I'm going to need you to kick into high gear here.
If you could just start off with just a brief description, we'll link to in show notes your
article at Breitbart, Texas describing what happened to this border agent.
If you could just give a little background and what you know so far as we stand here
Monday afternoon.
Well, initially, what we knew and what we reported was that very early on Sunday, November 19,
very early in the morning, two agents responded to some form of activity in the big bin sector,
roughly 30 something miles from the border in a town called Van Horn, near a town called
Van Horn, along night in.
And one of those agents ended up dead and another ended up hospitalized with serious
injuries.
That is what we initially knew.
Well, as the day trickled along, the FBI took over the investigation into what occurred.
There was a massive manhunt in response that's still going on, by the way, that's very rare
to see in a border region how large this is.
But federal authorities still refuse to say that there was a murder or to say what happened.
Well, thankfully, agents of the National Border Patrol Council said, wait a minute, like these
guys were ambushed and attacked by illegal aliens with rocks.
They were the scolas question.
These are the circumstances of what occurred.
So we ran with that.
We did not make that assertion.
We attributed it to the National Border Patrol Council and to other agents on the ground,
because that's their assertion.
But it's an assertion, I believe, to be true.
And there's a number of reasons that I do.
I state and some I don't state because of how I know those details, right?
And the damage, I think, sharing some of those details would do to sources and what have you.
And so at this moment, more than 24 hours has passed, and the FBI still has not made
a statement other than to say that an incident occurred and they're investigating it.
And they won't make a statement as to what occurred, but we can look at their activity
and what's happening.
And we can kind of get a gist that I can tell you that there had been multiple times that
Border Patrol agents have fallen and hit their heads and slipped.
In some cases, not remembered what occurred initially.
And they did not, federal authorities did not spend millions upon millions of tax dollars
flying over the area, searching the area, spreading out agents, a plethora of agencies
across the area.
So this is where we are right now.
We're in a place where people like me don't know if there's some legitimate reason that
the FBI and CBP are not releasing information or if they're simply doing it for political
purposes, which was very common during the Obama era.
In the Obama era, there was a downplaying of anything bad that happened on the border.
So it's possible that that's happening again.
We just simply don't know right now and we're just giving these agencies time to figure
out what they need to do.
I can tell you that they at least think there's a possibility.
I think they know that the agents were attacked, but there's at least a possibility in their
minds that this happened.
So I know that they have not warned local communities to be careful.
There might be a group of murderous people from a foreign country strolling around our
country.
I know that they have not warned people and I find that to be somewhat unforgivable,
and if they think there's a chance that happened.
So we just got to sit back and wait.
You know, Brandon, you're alluding to something really important here when you say, you know,
and I see you're being very careful because look, it's very fluid and we got to get to
the bottom of the details, but we know from past experience that somehow the border issue,
which should be a universal issue, always gets wrapped up in a, in a, in a, in the politics
of immigration.
What I find amazing is that, you know, we go overseas, we have wars all over the place.
We don't even know what we're doing in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Now our Niger and Yemen and Somalia, one study from Brown University released last week.
So we spent $4 trillion with this Islamic urban renewal projects over there.
But yet when we have a war right on our border, you know, to me, the hallmark of a first world
country versus a developing country, what distinguishes it from a developing country
is that you have full sovereignty over every inch of your, certainly interior, but even
border.
And yet here we clearly don't.
We clearly have a problem with drug cartels, forgetting about how much immigration you
want or do want.
But yet it's not universal in our body politic to deal with it.
Why do you think that's the case?
Well, I think there's a few things going on.
I think the first thing going on is that most of the people speaking about the border really
don't know what the hell they're talking about.
And I hate to say that in an ugly way, but it's actually true.
So what you have is you have, we have a media situation right now where most people get their
information by watching the television.
The television gives pundits, you know, 30 seconds to 60 seconds to talk and express
a point.
And most of those pundits just Google what people like you and I write and they don't
know what they're talking about.
So, you have that at the same time you have a polarized political situation where one
side insists the border is damaged and unsafe and a war zone.
The other side insists it's peaceful and okay.
And both of those are true and untrue, right?
Some areas of the border are safe.
Some of them are not.
Some areas of the border, the cartels don't really mess with people because there's a
different cartel controlling that area.
In some areas, especially south of Texas, we have very brutal cartels like Lizethas and
the Gulf cartel and they are very extremely brutal and they make sure that brutality is
expressed upon the general populace.
The average citizen, not just towards other drug cartel members or drug runners, right?
So you have all of these factors that play into people making generalizations.
They see a 2,000 mile border, you know, 1,993 mile border as though it's somehow this monolithic
community or monolithic place and it isn't.
There are different regions.
There's some cities oppose border security because they have a sister city that they've
always seen for the last 100 years as their same community.
There's two parts of a similar same community.
Well, they're obviously going to resist.
They're obviously going to resist dividing a permanent structure that divides the community.
And they're like a loved one who can't accept that their brother or sister has a drug addiction.
And every time the brother or sister tries to get sober, they welcome the brother and
sister back in the home.
The presidents are forgetting the history that every time the brother or sister comes
in, they take everything they own, right?
And that's like El Paso and Juarez.
Like Juarez is not a safe place.
But the people of El Paso, because they are similar communities and they are sister communities,
they're just out of the place to really cut off Juarez yet and allow some massive structure.
So there's all of these complex things, some which make you sound like a lefty if you say,
some which make you sound like a right wing authoritarian if you say, and a lot of them
are all true, right?
But there's not any effort to break that down and have a deeper conversation.
And then at the same time you have that dynamic occurring, right?
You have these generalizations being made.
But at the same time you have that, you have a situation on the right where, how do I say
it's the least controversial way possible, but I'm just going to try to be honest, you
have a situation on the right where you have traditional conservatism and then you have
more of the Austrian economic folks, right?
Like it or not, those situations, those ideologies are not congruent.
They're oil and water.
And there's some areas people can agree on, but not a whole lot.
And those disagreements actually have typicals that reach out everywhere.
So back in the Obama years when, you know, when Malcolm was really getting her start
and when when Leven was growing and when Andrew Brightmark started Big Government and, you
know, everyone on the right was in a foxhole together trying to build a movement, trying
to build a movement, support each other and challenge the left and the left media.
Well as time went on, that movement, you know, began to win and began to do okay and was
no longer in a foxhole, was no longer under siege.
And so the differences between us began to become a parent.
And that's kind of where we're at right now.
Some people want to blame it on Trump and it's not Trump.
But what it is is there are traditional conservatives who respect the concept of place
in loyal, theta place.
And then there are people who are much, who are very far on the other side with Austrian
economics who don't respect the concept of place.
So if I respect my community, my place and I feel an obligation in my place and to keep
my place okay, right, then I'm going to be called, I'm going to, by the other side of
the right, the more dominant side right now, I'm going to be called a liberal because
I want to see economics stimulus or I want to see economic development or I want to,
I won't just accept what the free market says and as Kevin Williamson in the National Review
just get a U-Haul and move.
And so those people are not necessarily going to respect place as much as I would more on
the traditional conservative side.
They're going to say free market, they're going to say so what if China and Russia make
all of our food and if everything's made there that's the free market tough, compete
or die.
And I don't look at it that way.
Well here's the catch though.
Those same people oftentimes will engage in supporting foreign wars and supporting foreign
intervention, supporting spending trillions in economic development and Islamic nations
halfway across the world are actually on the other side of it almost completely on
the other side of it.
But then if I want to spend money on things that would actually challenge cartels in the
border region both in the US, Oregon and Mexico, then I'm somehow a liberal even though what
I would spend of taxpayer dollars is a significant portion of percentage of what they're actually
supporting spending in the Middle East or in Africa or in this is where things get weird
because if you don't respect the politics of place, if you see everyone who supports
their community first as America first nationalist isolationist, well then you don't really support
the concept of a border because you don't respect place.
That's where the far right and the left actually start to merge and agree is that they start
to say hey wait a minute, we're one big amorphous world, one big amorphous market.
And it's like well if you think that way, why would you support border security?
Why would you focus on things, on the problems that result from not having enough border
security? Because you wouldn't focus on that because it challenges your worldview.
And that's where the problem is with the conservatives and I'm sorry I'm doing this but
with conservatives and then the far right neoliberal, yeah that neoliberal, but I got more
profitable liberals. Right, right the problem is in this is that we are members of an economy,
right? We are parts of an economy, our financial economy really matters. They're right.
But the problem is you have to balance that with the recognition that we are also citizens
of a nation. We are also members of a place. We also use our tax dollars and maybe we want
to help the world but ultimately we expect our government to help us first.
Sure and obviously and then the world, the ultimate market is built upon private property,
right? So you got to have your private property and I'm thinking, you know again going back to
this juxtaposition that you mentioned, so many foreign wars we do, we spend so much money
because maybe, maybe if we get the right people in Nigeria and hold the right ground in Yemen
and Somalia and Kabul, somehow it won't affect us even though ultimately it only affects us if
they immigrate here and it's an immigration problem. But then ironically at our borders,
see this is what I don't understand and I get, you know people want open borders for economic
reasons but when you get to a point where you have your own property that it's just no longer safe,
that's what's amazing that it's become that political to that extent. You know I messaged you
earlier today and I hopefully could speak a little bit to the situation inland, you know not just
on the border but I was surprised when he talked about Van Horn where this attack seemed to have
taken place that killed the border agent, it's about 30 miles into Texas, it's not right at the
border. So that means if this indeed was an ambush, you have an ambush of foreign nationals
on a border patrol agent 30 miles into our border, into our own property.
Yeah but this is not, this is, I mean last month we broke this story and we had to prove it,
it was very difficult to prove, I knew it forever but we broke that one faction of the Cinoloa
cartel was sending their scouts and their smugglers into our territory with AK-4 armed with longas,
you know some cases AK-4-7s and I finally got video of it and proof of it and photographic evidence
that this was occurring and finally after years of me trying CBP, Customs and Border Protection,
admitted yes this was happening, only once I had the photos. On our own soil. And this is
on our own soil and but it's not, you know that's what the, that's what I'm trying to express to people
is that we're not, how do I say this and I really do try to not be offensive, I try to be nice and I
try to, I try to be kind but we are not talking about the US border with Canada, right? It's a,
that's a shared border between two nations where they have the rule of law existing on both sides
where the majority of people in both countries have, they have economic opportunities and they
have the ability to have some form of redress when their governments do wrong or fleece them,
we're not talking about the US border with Canada, we're talking about the US border with Mexico,
okay? And so the US border with Mexico is a border with a country that has vast regions,
entire states that are directly under the control of cartels or if you want to be academic transnational
criminal organizations, it's Mexico, it's a nation where they're almost a failed narco state
where even their current president has direct ties with the very narco cartels that have killed
roughly 125 and 1000 human beings in the last two years and made missing 30 to 50,000 human
beings who were just forever gone. That's what we're talking about when there's when there's
such a disparity economically in the rule of law, when there's such a disparity between two places,
you have to find ways, you have to find ways to prevent that chaos from affecting the lives
of your own citizens. Exactly. And that's what that's where I wanted to take this conversation next,
Brandon, that you know, I find it again astounding, amazing how in the political class, both sides,
both parties, they'll talk about, man, we wouldn't want to destabilize Iraq, we wouldn't want Afghanistan
to be destabilized. And you know, we left because you know, you can't get more destabilized than
it already is. But you know, we don't want to destabilize Nigeria. And then we have this insane
destabilization right on our border spilling into our own soil. Like you said, 125,000 people
killed, you have Juarez is just the stone throws across the river. And it's as bad as anything in
the Middle East or you know, in terms of violence. What are some of the ideas based on your experience
really traveling the border, living the area that you think is a matter of public policy
that we should embrace in dealing with the border and refocusing our priorities?
Well, okay. So here's a lot of you might not realize this, but for the last roughly four years
of my life, okay, there are nine sectors on the Southwest border. For the last four years of my
life, I've spent at least 10 days a month traveling those nine sectors. Sometimes I hit one sector,
sometimes I hit three, sometimes in those 10 days I've hit all nine, you know, listening to
agents, listening to immigrants advocates, listening to drug counselors, listening to local police
and local sheriffs, listening to federal agents. And then about two years ago, we started the
cartel chronicles. So I started doing the same thing in Mexico. So we have the most
comprehensive knowledge of the border region, which is not just the US. The border region is
composed of the US side and the Mexico side. Sure. And we have the most complex knowledge of that
of that environment and that ecosystem or the various ecosystems in that region.
Then again, I don't say that to toot my own horn, even though it kind of does, but I mean,
we just understand it. And it's myself and the only funds that were to tease, we just have a very,
we're very intimately involved with that region. And what we've learned is that there are in fact
some areas that need physical barriers. There are. We have some areas on our border with Mexico
that have physical barriers and they work very well. Some areas where they have different types
of physical barriers that don't work very well. Are you talking about areas?
Human San Diego. Well, we have we have areas where we in San Diego sector, part of the San
Diego sector, we have a legitimate concrete wall that works. And then we have other parts of the
San Diego sector where we have just the primary fence that's four feet tall and it doesn't work.
You go on the way to Yuma. There's a stretch of the Yuma sector that has a three-tiered fencing
system, which is I think the most secured part of the US-Mexico border in it.
Brandon, where aren't those part of the 36 miles that we started?
Listen, I want to get through this though. I want to say this because I could walk you down the line
and every 40 to 20 miles is different of that 1,993. And I know it by memory. And what I'm telling
you is this is even though physical barriers are necessary in some areas, they have a lot less to
do with border security than a number of other things do. They even have border patrol agents
themselves are vital in the way they're distributed and having more is actually necessary. But
they themselves are there's more we could do that would have more to do with border security than
the agents or the barriers or even the technology itself. And that's what no one talks about.
We don't have enough US Attorney's Office resources on the border. So they can't prosecute everyone
who needs to be prosecuted under like broken windows theory or they can. And not only that,
the majority of people who come across the border, even if you built a wall to the moon,
like 5,000 times as intense as the DMD in North Korea and South Korea between on the
38th parallel, right? Even if you have that, it would stop very little of the drugs and people
coming into this country because the majority of narcotics and the majority of people who come
illegally do not come between ports of entry. They come through the ports of entry. They either
overwhelm our agencies or they pay people in those agencies. Public corruption is a major problem.
And so even if you have the biggest, there was just no way to get through accepted ports of entry,
it would still not change very much. So in order to address that, you have to increase the
federal Bureau of Investigation resources and you have to increase Homeland Security
Investigation resources and IRS resources. And I mean, go down the line because you have to be
able to monitor these federal agents and make sure there's not public corruption or else you're
not going to achieve much at all. And then in addition to those things, we look at Mexico,
our state department, through the Merida initiative, there's a program called I&L,
which is the International Narcotics and Non-enforcement. Okay.
Yeah, I want to talk about that, Merida. The way that our state department works,
is they actually end up protecting significant cartel figures. That's what they do because
in a country where the majority of politicians are connected to the cartel, the only way that
you can have good diplomacy with that country for trade is to in fact be lenient upon the cartels
who are the lifeblood of how the Mexican politicians have money. And so the whole system is messed up.
So border security has a lot more to do with that than it does with a wall or anything we
actually do on our actual border between ports of entry. And then you get into some really
trippy stuff and you start going, okay, I know for a fact, I used to hate cartels. I hated cartels.
And now I'm like, you know, I hate a lot of the leadership, but a lot of the people who are just
the gunmen and the smugglers and the, do you know what? They grew up in a situation. I am not joking
and when I say poor, I'm talking poor. They grew up in a situation where they had no other
mechanisms to do well. They had no other mechanism to have a vehicle, to feed their families,
to feel like they had any power, any dignity is mid. And so you start looking at that. You're like,
why are we investing in the economic development of these countries across the world when we're
not investing in the economic development there? And in order to invest in the economic development,
it requires security there. And in order for there to be security there, we have to go after
cartels. But in order to go after cartels, we have to go after Mexican political figures.
And he starts to get very complicated. But ultimately what it boils down to is we will never
secure the border. We will never limit the heroin, the fentanyl, the methamphetamine coming from
Mexico. It will never, the people coming. We will never limit that. The way that we're doing this,
no matter what we throw at the border. And then you get into pool and push factors
in a regular migration, we call a legal immigration once across our border. You get into that. And
that needs to be fixed too. And there needs to be some really intense policies, which is,
and the only way you can engage in those really intense policies, regardless of what you think
is right or wrong, because we do live in a country that is so divided where half of us still one
way and half of us still another. The only way that you're going to get policy that limits illegal
immigration, which is to say, hey, if you come here illegally, it doesn't matter who you are,
where you are, where you're from, why you came, you're going home right away. If you come twice,
you're going to jail. Don't. The only way you're going to get that is by having legitimate
increase in heavily regulated worker programs. It's a complex issue, but it can be resolved and
solved. It can be fixed. But not with our current climate, because like I said, most of the people
talking about it talk about it for 30 seconds. They make sweeping generalizations that do not
serve to inform the public. And people like me, like if Hannity said, and I love him,
not knocking Hannity, but if Hannity says, hey, would you come on? I'm like, I'm not going to fly to
Dallas to be on your show for 30 seconds. Like I would go talk to Charlie Rose, or I would talk
to you on this format because we can talk it later. We can actually have a talk at length. Yep.
But it has to happen that way. And this is the problem that we're in right now. We're in a problem
where the politics around the issue, the knee jerk politics, the oversimplification,
which is largely caused because of the way we do media. Sure. The culture, the media culture in
our country, the political culture in our country. And what if someone can't say something new on?
If they say something new on, it gets used against them in a primary session, in a primary season,
in a primary, you know, it's just unbelievable. A little bit for our listeners. What I get from
what you're saying is that, you know, whenever we discuss the border, immediately it gets, you know,
involved with immigration politics, both right, left, everyone has their talking points. But what
you're saying is there's something much deeper. We talk about our solution to the symptoms. Some
of them are counterintuitive. Amnesty Amnesty or do this or build a wall. But there's the source
of the problem. And there's the use of statecraft to deal with the fact that we have a failed state
on our border. You know, we all we have this national debate. We've had it for decades about
should we engage in nation building? But putting that aside for a minute, what we are doing is
engaging in nation building around the world. But if I had to ask you, if you believe in nation
building, what is the one nation you should build? It should be the one on our border, you know,
that we should want a stable Mexico that that's the best of everyone. If Mexico was okay,
if Mexico, Mexico has vast resources to do well. Sure. Well, if Mexico was okay,
nobody, even if we were able to make one state in Mexico, okay, out of their 32 or 33, I believe,
if Mexico were to be okay, everyone coming from the south of Mexico would stay in Mexico.
Exactly. Well, we not only that, but everyone in Mexico would stay in Mexico. And it's just,
it's almost to me, um, that's it's so clear to me what what what the things are to be done.
But even in a situation where my former employer who started this cartel and border project with me
was in the West Wing, you know, to me, and it's kind of like similar to something that
Kofi Annan once said, it's like, I have a plan and I can see how to fix all of this. But the
problem is, is I have to implement the plan through people, you know, and and and I think that's what
the problem is here. I really do. And I think in our current climate, we're not going to have a fix
to this. We can keep addressing symptoms and we can we can keep addressing the consequences
and trying to limit consequences. It'll just pop up somewhere else, uh, as long as we want to,
but that we're not going to have a fix in our current environment because
no one's being honest. No one no one can be honest. If I ran for office, like things I said in this
very interview, even though I'm advocating a right of center strong, it'd be very difficult to call
me an open borders advocate, right? But that someone would take some slice of what I just said in
this interview because there's nuance that I'm talking in detail and they would use it to like
make campaign ads. You see that nobody wants to be that person. It can only push their talking
point. It's definitely political talking court. Yeah, it's definitely political problem. But I
think it's also it's an intellectual problem too. Like you said, everyone will bother. I mean, I
actually think they don't bother anymore, but originally to understand well, there's 15 tribes
in Afghanistan and here are the dynamics and you win hearts and minds and we got to build up their
economy and this and that. And the problem here is we don't even think about it. No one's even
discussing this from a total like you're saying, you know, put on a shelf while you believe with
amnesty security. I have very strong beliefs on that. But this is aside from it. And really,
the antecedent to the whole problem is that if you just took a fraction of the funds and focus that
we expend towards who knows what we're doing in the Middle East and actually focus on a stable
Mexico, you know, we hear from a lot of bleeding hearts in our country, you're not allowed to
care about your own people evidently, but it's all for the Mexican people. All right. Well, if you
care about the Mexican people, you should want to save them from the cartels and the violence.
And the only way to do that is not to continue just the circuitous smuggling amnesty cycle,
which is only going to fuel it. You got to address the source of the problem.
We're right here. The problem, brother. Here's the problem is that many of our donors on the
Republican side, they have business models that are based off of the cheap labor and exploitation
of foreign labor. And not only that, but many of the people on the left side, they don't want
the people of Mexico to stay in Mexico. They want them to come here and vote.
See, everyone has an interest here. And in the middle, somewhere in the middle of all those people
are the majority of us, which are normal people who either think, hey, we're not helping. It's
Unhumanitarian. We're not helping American, America's poor workers, and we're not helping people in
Mexico by having this unfettered immigration. And then you have the left to honestly believe that
they're doing it to help those people. And somewhere in the middle of the two extremes are all of
the rest of us who are like, you know, this is a complex issue. I understand why they come,
but at the same time here are economic consequences at the same time, blah, blah. But we're not the
ones running the show, brother. The ones running the show are the people on the extreme. There's
some people want voters and some people want exploitative foreign labor. That's the problem.
It's a significant issue to deal with. And I don't quite know how to resolve that politically,
but I do know that doing things like this, where we talk together and have people consider this,
I think a good start. No, exactly. And that's what I always say. My motto here is, you know,
how good policy doesn't fit on a bumper sticker. That's why we have this long
forum where you don't have that 30 second sound bite. I've quit the Fox circuit. I can't stand it.
One more quick question. We're running at a time. But you mentioned something I was very interested in.
And I wanted to know kind of what the state of play is what you think needs to be done. The
Merida initiative, my understanding is from FY 2008 to FY 2017, we've spent about $2.8 billion.
Supposedly, it was to clean up the corruption, tackle crime in Mexico. But clearly, those funds
haven't been landing where they need to. What's the basic background and where that program stands?
Well, I mean, there's some aspects of the program that work, but we have to remember something.
The majority of the dollars that go into the Mexican government for initiatives
never get to the people they're supposed to get to. People at the top take those dollars,
and by the time they get to their law enforcement agencies along the border,
they're left without graphite for taking fingerprints. They're left without training.
They never get, they have to buy a lot of their own paper to make copies. If they even have a copy
machine, I mean, it's that type of poverty. So basically what we're doing is we're spending
billions of US dollars or hundreds of millions at least, you know, if you, because I think it's
